timeline.summary: An email chain discusses the last recorded deed for Little St. James Island. The deed, dated December 23, 2011, shows L.S.I. LLC (formerly Epstein) as the grantor to Nautilus Inc., with Jeffrey E. Epstein as the sole beneficial owner and president.  Inquiries are made regarding deeds from 1998 and 2002-2005, specifically to investigate potential asset violations. Travel authorization and photographic inventory of assets are requested.

Multiple requests were made for travel authorization to conduct meetings and interviews related to the United States v. Epstein investigation, specifically concerning enticement of minors for sexual activity. These requests involved travel to West Palm Beach, Florida, and potentially Fort Lauderdale.  Flight plans varied, including a proposed Tuesday night departure and Wednesday/Thursday or Friday return.  Approvals were granted by multiple individuals, with some confirmations and one offering to book a conference room at the hotel.  One request involved a change to the original plan to fly directly to San Francisco due to scheduling conflicts related to a wedding.  Recipient addresses and subject lines are redacted.

This document pertains to travel authorization requests for investigations related to the Epstein case (2018R01618), specifically involving interviews with victims in Florida and Los Angeles. Requests are made for travel, including airfare, accommodation, and conference room reservations, typically spanning a few days. Approvals are consistently granted, often referencing specific dates and locations (Palm Beach, Florida, Los Angeles, West Palm Beach, Fort Lauderdale). Standard travel guidelines are outlined, including restrictions on vehicle rentals (compact/economy), reimbursement policies (no refueling charges, tax exemptions), and expense reporting procedures (same-day submission). The requests repeatedly emphasize a need for short trip durations and quick scheduling decisions.

The document is a series of email exchanges related to travel authorization requests for investigations concerning the Epstein case (2018R01618). Requests involve travel to Florida (Palm Beach, West Palm Beach, Fort Lauderdale) and Los Angeles for victim interviews. Specific details include requested travel dates, duration, and a request for conference room reservations. Standard travel procedures are outlined, such as utilizing specific vehicle types, adhering to per diem rates, submitting receipts promptly, and using designated E2 solutions for booking. Approvals were granted for multiple trips.

This document is a record of travel approval requests related to an ongoing investigation, “United States v. Epstein” (2018R01618), concerning enticement of minors for sexual activity. Multiple requests were submitted to authorize travel to Florida (Palm Beach, West Palm Beach, and Los Angeles) and potentially Fort Lauderdale, for interviews and meetings.  Standard procedures included utilizing E2 solutions for booking travel, adhering to specific vehicle rental guidelines (compact/economy vehicles, no insurance in CONUS), and submitting receipts the day after the trip. Approvals were granted for conference room reservations and the travel was primarily driven by the need to interview victims. The requests emphasized minimizing trip duration and using cost-effective options when available.

Travel authorization 10415581 was approved for a trip to West Palm Beach, FL, from 2019-07-11 to 2019-07-14, related to “U.S. v. Epstein (2018R0618) - Victim Interviews.” The authorization is currently pending further approval. Links to E2 Single Sign On and Manual Login are provided for the DOJ Network. The email includes reference ID# T0007 and a disclaimer regarding confidential information.

On August 14, 2019, a Financial Program Specialist at the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) responded to a question regarding per diem eligibility for staff traveling over 50 miles and exceeding 12 hours. The BOP-ADM/Acct Policy & Procedures, referencing GSA FTR 301-11.1, states that per diem is granted if the trip is over 12 hours and over 50 miles.  A subsequent page contains irrelevant text and a different document number (EFTA00036872).

The email chain pertains to travel arrangements for a USANYS traveler to Sweden, scheduled for February 3rd and 4th, 2020. Key details include: *   An ECC request package (ECC\_package\_2.3.20.pdf) was attached, requiring the traveler to determine the POC and check for visa requirements. *   EOUSA needs to be notified of visa requests and the traveler's OIA approval email. *   The traveler submitted a corrected itinerary (February 4th - 6th) and a questionnaire for review. *   A travel authorization is being routed to the traveler’s trip. *   Submission of the visa request package to EOUSA/RMP Travel is recommended 5 business days prior to departure.

An email request is being submitted for travel to Stockholm, Sweden, for an Assistant U.S. Attorney and two other individuals (AUSAs S and S) by the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York. The request includes an ECC package (ECC_package_2.3.2.20.pdf) and instructions for the traveler to determine the Point of Contact (POC), check for visa requirements via the State Department’s website, and submit the visa request package to EOUSA-RMP Travel at least 15 business days prior to departure to allow sufficient time for State Dept. authorization and foreign government processing. The delay in submission is due to a recently confirmed witness interview date.

*   The travel request includes details of the trip dates (October xx to October Yu, 2020) and the purpose of the visit. *   Multiple individuals (including USAEO-Foreign Travel, Assistant US Attorneys, and an iPad user) are involved in coordinating the travel approval and visa requirements. *   A visa is not required for the trip. *   A travel memo is attached to facilitate the approval process. *   The email chain involves requests for the recipient to forward approval for a travel authorization and provide information regarding the point of contact (POC) and additional steps for the traveler.

AUSA requested travel arrangements for two witnesses – [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] – to appear in SDNY for trial preparation related to the Ghislaine Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330). Both witnesses are considered fact witnesses and victims-witnesses. They require hotel accommodations and will be accompanied by their husband and three minor children for emotional support due to the trauma associated with testifying about past abuse.  The request includes details regarding unusual expenses, specifically the travel of the family unit, and instructions for travel authorization, including guidelines for witness travel and potential use of the FEWS appropriation.

*   The package included an itinerary and requested information regarding a Point of Contact (POC) and visa requirements. *   The sender was requesting approval for the travel authorization and awaiting OIA (Office of Intelligence Analysis) approval. *   Attachments included a draft ECC package, a questionnaire, and a flight itinerary. *   Communication involved multiple individuals and departments including USAEO-Foreign Travel, USANYS, and OIA. *   The document’s creation date was 2025-12-26.
